author: Aloysius Xavier Lopez
text:
Hike unlikely as Assembly and local body polls are scheduled this year

Even though higher taxes and user charges will automatically follow improved services in a Smart City, residents can take comfort in the fact that the State government is unlikely to take any sudden decision to increase taxes and user charges during the election year.

With the Assembly and local body elections scheduled this year, the State government is unlikely to take any decision to increase revenue receipts, including property tax.

Chennai Corporation collects just Rs. 600 crore as property tax every year. The plan is to increase the property tax collection to at least Rs. 2,000 crore.

As no increase cannot be effected this year, implementation of a few smart proposals may suffer.

Pedestrian plaza

The pedestrian plaza, which has been included in the Smart City proposal for T. Nagar, has also been delayed due to lack of funding for the project.

Given this, the civic body is expected to borrow heavily from development banks, float municipal bonds and use land-based financing instruments based on the recommendations of the Fourteenth Finance Commission.

The government is also expected to increase conversion charges collected at the time of change in land use and levy a betterment tax for areas covered under the Smart Cities project.

Finance Commission

Some of the recommendations of the 14th Finance Commission include higher charges for claiming additional Floor Space Index as a right.

The Corporation could use these instruments, but to do so, they need approval from the State government.

In addition to the Rs.100-crore funding from the Central government and a matching contribution by the State government, this year at least Rs. 500 crore is expected to be spent on the Smart City proposals.

“We will explore options such as public-private partnerships, land-based instruments, municipal bonds and borrowings. But convergence with other government schemes will hold the key to implementation of some proposals this year,” said an official.

Based on the project by the Department of Economic Affairs for assessing Chennai for credit-worthiness and bond-readiness, work on yet another transaction could also be taken up shortly.

title: Higher taxes will follow, not for now
